central_thesis: This edition of The Scroll of Set outlines the Temple of Set's distinct philosophical and operative identity as a Left-Hand Path successor to older occult orders, emphasizing individual will, conscious evolution (Xepera), and the rejection of theological syncretism, while also addressing internal community matters and legal challenges.

structure_content.chapter_title: [1] To the Members of the Temple of Set
structure_content.summary: Lilith Sinclair expresses profound gratitude to the Temple members for their support in her civil rights lawsuit. She frames her stand as a crucial act for all Setians, embodying a commitment to principle (vow to the Prince of Darkness) over personal convenience, and a precedent for the philosophical persuasion.

This article details a fundraising raffle event held by Temple members to support Lilith Sinclair's lawsuit. It describes the drawing of winning tickets, the specific prizes awarded, and confirms the financial success of the initiative, with proceeds designated for legal costs and potential future Temple treasury use.

Michael A. Aquino V° critically differentiates the Temple of Set from the A.'.A.'. and O.T.O. He posits the Temple of Set as a successor that selectively integrates worthwhile aspects of older systems while discarding obsolete ones. Aquino critiques the older orders' philosophical inconsistencies, their Right-Hand Path orientation (seeking union with the universe), and Crowley's handling of diverse theologies. He contrasts this with the Temple of Set's adaptable, Left-Hand Path design focused on individual distinction and will-driven reality creation.

structure_content.chapter_title: [4] Ye Scroll Editor is On Strike
structure_content.summary: A brief, humorous note indicating the editor's strike participation alongside others.
An introduction to the subsequent magical invocation by L. Dale Seago, highlighting its confidential nature and importance.

This section presents a magical invocation (in transliterated Egyptian and English) to Set. It describes the practitioner's process of self-gathering, entering into Set, and asserting individual will and intellect to become a Setian and 'heir of eternity'. It is a ritual text for individual transformation and self-creation, demonstrating the practical application of Setian philosophy.

The editor addresses mail regarding political issues unsuitable for publication due to organizational by-laws. However, it encourages internal discussion among Setians on moral and ethical topics (e.g., 'right to die', abortion) to foster understanding of diverse Setian perspectives compared to external views.

key_concepts.definition: An occult organization designed to be a living, adaptable system capable of incorporating new knowledge, succeeding older orders like the A.'.A.'. and O.T.O. by selectively integrating valuable material and discarding obsolete elements, explicitly following the Left-Hand Path.

The identifying characteristic of Setian philosophy, involving the deliberate separation and distinction of the individual from the objective universe, the development and maintenance of a strong will (presence of mind), and the conscious redesign of one's perceptual reality according to that will. It emphasizes individuation and self-deification.

Philosophies (including conventional religions and, as critiqued, the A.'.A.'. and O.T.O.) that seek to unite individual consciousness with a greater entity (God, Universe) to obliterate the 'unnatural self' and return to non-conscious harmony with nature.

An Egyptian phrase translated as 'I rise, even I; may I gather myself together, entering to Set.' It represents the core Setian process of self-creation, becoming, and the assertion of individual consciousness and will in a transformative magical context.
Referred to by the Temple of Set as an independent intelligence, contrasting with Crowley's later interpretation of 'gods' as merely subjective aspects of human personality.

As interpreted by Crowley, these were subjective aspects of the human personality, allowing an 'invoked god' to be whatever Crowley desired it to be. The Temple of Set rejects this interpretation for entities like Aiwass.

practical_system.description: The Temple of Set's practical system is rooted in the Left-Hand Path, focusing on the individual's conscious evolution ('Xepera') and the deliberate strengthening of personal will. It involves the 'separation and distinction of the individual from the objective universe' and the capacity to 'redesign his perceptual universe in accordance with his will'. This system is designed to be adaptable and rejects the 'sloppy' theological syncretism seen in older orders. The core practice is the development and assertion of individual consciousness and intellect.
tools: Consciousness (as a faculty to be strengthened and expanded)
Pentagram (as a symbol of personal identity and commitment, as worn by Lilith Sinclair)
rituals: The 'Xepera Xeper Xeperu' invocation, exemplified in the text, involves a direct address to Set, a declaration of self-gathering and entering into Set, and an affirmation of individual will, intellect, and power to achieve self-creation and eternal becoming. This suggests a practice of internal transformation and external assertion through a formal magical statement.

relevant_quotes.text: This is the identifying characteristic of the Left-Hand Path, which involves the separation and distinction of the individual from the objective universe. To develop and sustain such a presence of mind (will) is extremely difficult, because it involves the systematic wrenching-loose of the mind from the multitude of natural influences which constantly surround it.

The position of the Temple of Set is not that it is a competitor to the A.'.A.'. & O.T.O., but rather that it is their successor [as well as the successor to the Church of Satan]. This implies that we have considered & evaluated what the old organizations had to offer, incorporated the worthwhile material into the Temple, and selectively dispensed with the obsolete and/or inaccurate material.

The A.'.A.'. & O.T.O. are very sloppy in their philosophical logic. They mix theologies which by their conceptual definitions are mutually exclusive: Chinese, Hindu, Masonic, Hebrew, Egyptian, Catholic, etc. Crowley, in point of fact, was well aware of this problem. He attempted to handle it via two identifiable measures: (1) He attempted to define all religions and philosophies as variations of a common theme... (2) He identified 'gods' as subjective aspects of the human personality.

So how did Crowley manage it? The answer is that he did not renounce his consciousness. Rather he strengthened and expanded it to the point that he was able to redesign his perceptual universe in accordance with his will.

Xepera Xeper Xeperu. May I rise, even I; may I gather myself together, entering to Set. Hail Set, One, maker of mankind and of the substance of the gods of the south, east, north, and west! Ascribe praise to Set, Lord of Darkness, the Prince, creator of the gods. Adore ye him in his beautiful presence.

critical_analysis.relevance: This document is crucial for understanding the foundational principles and early self-identity of the Temple of Set within Western Esotericism. It clearly articulates the Temple's unique Left-Hand Path philosophy, distinguishing it sharply from Thelemic orders (A.'.A.'. and O.T.O.) by critiquing their perceived Right-Hand Path aims and philosophical inconsistencies. The text serves as both a philosophical manifesto and an internal communiqué, revealing the practicalities of community support and the dynamic evolution of Setian thought during its formative years.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The primary audience is existing members of the Temple of Set, for internal cohesion, philosophical guidance, and updates on organizational activities. A secondary audience includes serious academic researchers and practitioners of Western Esotericism, particularly those interested in the history of modern occultism, the development of the Left-Hand Path, and the specific doctrines of the Temple of Set and its relationship to other magical traditions.
